## Introduction

In January 2017, Buzzfeed published an article on why Nobel laureates show immigration is so important for American science. You can read the article [here](https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/peteraldhous/immigration-and-science). In the article they show that while most living Nobel laureates in the sciences are based in the US, many of them were born in other countries. This is one reason why scientific leaders say that immigration is vital for progress. 

In this lab we will work with the data from this article to recreate some of their visualizations as well as explore new questions.

**Estimated time:** 90-120 minutes

## Learning Goals

By the end of this lab, you will be able to:

- Replicate published data visualizations
- Use `mutate()` with `if_else()` to create new variables
- Filter data based on multiple conditions
- Create faceted bar plots
- Create stacked/segmented bar plots
- Interpret visualizations in context of real-world questions

## Understanding Merge Conflicts

As you work with Git and GitHub, you may occasionally encounter **merge conflicts**. While less common when working independently, it's important to understand what they are.

**What causes a merge conflict?**

A merge conflict occurs when:

- You make changes to your local files
- Someone else (or you on another computer) makes different changes to the same part of the same file on GitHub
- Git can't automatically determine which changes to keep

**What does a merge conflict look like?**

Git puts conflict markers in your code:
```         
<<<<<<< HEAD 
Your changes are here
======= 
Their changes are here
>>>>>>> hash123abc
```

**How to resolve a merge conflict:**

  Step 1. Edit the file to keep the changes you want
  
  Step 2. Delete the `<<<`, `===`, and `>>>` markers
  
  step 3. Save the file
  
  Step 4. Stage, commit, and push

**Best practices to avoid merge conflicts:**

- Always **pull** before you start working
- **Commit and push** frequently
- If you do get a conflict, resolve it immediately before continuing work
- When in doubt, ask for help!

## Data

The dataset for this assignment can be found as a CSV (comma separated values) file in the `data` folder of your repository. You can read it in using the following.

```{r load-data, message = FALSE}
nobel <- read_csv("data/nobel.csv")
```

The variable descriptions are as follows:

-   `id`: ID number
-   `firstname`: First name of laureate
-   `surname`: Surname
-   `year`: Year prize won
-   `category`: Category of prize
-   `affiliation`: Affiliation of laureate
-   `city`: City of laureate in prize year
-   `country`: Country of laureate in prize year
-   `born_date`: Birth date of laureate
-   `died_date`: Death date of laureate
-   `gender`: Gender of laureate
-   `born_city`: City where laureate was born
-   `born_country`: Country where laureate was born
-   `born_country_code`: Code of country where laureate was born
-   `died_city`: City where laureate died
-   `died_country`: Country where laureate died
-   `died_country_code`: Code of country where laureate died
-   `overall_motivation`: Overall motivation for recognition
-   `share`: Number of other winners award is shared with
-   `motivation`: Motivation for recognition

In a few cases the name of the city/country changed after laureate was given (e.g. in 1975 Bosnia and Herzegovina was called the Socialist Federative Republic of Yugoslavia). In these cases the variables below reflect a different name than their counterparts without the suffix `_original`.

-   `born_country_original`: Original country where laureate was born
-   `born_city_original`: Original city where laureate was born
-   `died_country_original`: Original country where laureate died
-   `died_city_original`: Original city where laureate died
-   `city_original`: Original city where laureate lived at the time of winning the award
-   `country_original`: Original country where laureate lived at the time of winning the award

**‚úì Checkpoint:** Run `glimpse(nobel)` in your Console to verify the data loaded correctly. You should see 935 observations and 26 variables.

## Most Living Nobel Laureates Were Based in the US When They Won Their Prizes

... says the Buzzfeed article. Let's see if that's true.

First, we'll create a new variable to identify whether the laureate was in the US when they won their prize. We'll use the `mutate()` function for this. The following pipeline mutates the `nobel_living` data frame by adding a new variable called `country_us`. We use an if statement to create this variable.

```{marginfigure}
The `if_else()` function tests a condition. If TRUE, it returns the first value ("USA"); if FALSE, it returns the second value ("Other").
```

```{r create-country-us, eval = FALSE}
nobel_living %>%
  mutate(
    country_us = if_else(country == "USA", "USA", "Other")
  )
```

**What this code does:**

- If `country` equals `"USA"`, set `country_us` to `"USA"`
- Otherwise, set `country_us` to `"Other"`

Next, we will limit our analysis to only the following categories: Physics, Medicine, Chemistry, and Economics.

```{r create-science-data, eval = FALSE}
nobel_living_science  <- nobel_living %>%
  filter(category %in% c("Physics", "Medicine", "Chemistry", "Economics"))
```

**Important:** Make sure you run both code chunks above! You'll need the `nobel_living_science` data frame for the next exercise.

## Common Errors and Troubleshooting

**Data wrangling errors:**

- **Error: "object 'nobel_living' not found"** ‚Üí Make sure you ran the code chunk that creates this data frame
- **Error: "object 'nobel_living_science' not found"** ‚Üí Make sure you ran the code chunk that creates this filtered data frame
- **Filter not working as expected** ‚Üí Check your logic: `==` for equals, `!=` for not equals, `is.na()` for missing values
- **`if_else()` not working** ‚Üí Make sure the condition comes first, then the TRUE value, then the FALSE value

**Visualization errors:**

- **Bars not showing correctly** ‚Üí Check that you're using the right variable for x-axis and fill
- **Facets not appearing** ‚Üí Make sure you're using `facet_wrap(~category)` with the tilde
- **Bars are vertical instead of horizontal** ‚Üí Add `coord_flip()` to your plot
- **Colors not showing segments** ‚Üí Use `fill = born_country_us` inside `aes()`, not `color`

**General issues:**

- **Code chunk not running** ‚Üí Make sure you changed `eval=FALSE` to `eval=TRUE`
- **Inline code not working** ‚Üí Use backticks with r 
- **Changes not on GitHub** ‚Üí Remember to commit AND push
